--- title: "Tesla Stock in 2010 vs. Tesla Car: Which Was the Smarter Investment?" author: "Nahar Singh Namdhari" date: "2024-09-18" categories: [news, website] image: "../../images/Tesla2.jpg" format: html: code-fold: true --- ## Tesla Stock in 2010 vs. Tesla Car: Which Was the Smarter Investment? ### Introduction In 2010, Tesla was a relatively unknown player in the automotive industry, having just launched its revolutionary but niche Tesla Roadster. At the time, many were skeptical about the company’s long-term viability, and Tesla's newly issued stock, following its IPO (Initial Public Offering), was considered a risky investment. The choice between purchasing an innovative electric vehicle or investing in Tesla’s future presented a clear financial dilemma: should one buy the luxury Tesla Roadster for instant enjoyment, or invest in the company’s ambitious future, despite the risks? ### Methods #### Data Source This analysis relies on two primary data sources: - **Tesla Stock Data**: Retrieved from [**Yahoo Finance**](https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/TSLA/history/), the dataset includes adjusted closing prices for Tesla stock spanning from 2010 to 2024. This data was used to compute the investment returns over the 14-year period. To ensure its quality, the dataset was thoroughly examined for completeness, covering the entire timeframe. No missing values or outliers were detected during the review process. The data was downloaded by first clicking on "Historical Data," selecting the desired date range, and then clicking the "Download" button. - **Tesla Roadster Depreciation Data**: The depreciation data for luxury electric vehicles was sourced from industry-leading platforms, [**Kelley Blue Book**](https://www.kbb.com) and [**Edmunds**](https://www.edmunds.com), both recognized for their accuracy and reliability. To ensure consistency, the data was cross-referenced between the two platforms. It was then applied to a standard depreciation model for luxury electric vehicles in R studio. #### Data Description The dataset consists of the following key variables: - **Date**: The recorded date of Tesla's stock price or the Tesla Roadster's valuation. - **Adj_Close**: The adjusted closing price of Tesla stock, accounting for corporate actions like stock splits or dividends. - **Investment_Value**: The changing value of a $109,000 investment in Tesla stock or the depreciation of the Tesla Roadster over time. - **Shares_Purchased**: The number of Tesla shares that could be bought with $109,000 in 2010. #### Details of Work Done 1. **Stock Investment Calculation**: - The adjusted closing price of Tesla stock on June 30, 2010, was used to determine the number of shares that could be purchased with the initial $109,000. This amounted to approximately 28,385 shares. The value of this investment was then calculated annually based on the adjusted closing prices for each year, illustrating the exponential growth in value over the 14-year period (see @fig-tesla-stock). ::: {.cell} ::: 2. **Depreciation Calculation for Tesla Roadster**: - The Roadster’s initial purchase price of $109,000 in 2010 was subject to a 20% depreciation in the first year, followed by a 10% annual depreciation over the next four years. After this period, the depreciation slowed to 5% per year. By 2020, the car's value began to stabilize, showing a typical depreciation pattern for luxury vehicles over time (see @tbl-roadster). ::: {.cell} ::: ### Key Results ***Tesla Stock Investment*** A $109,000 investment in Tesla stock on June 30, 2010, at an adjusted price of $3.84 per share, would have secured approximately 28,385 shares. By June 30, 2024, this investment would have soared in value to $14.39 million, reflecting a staggering return of over 13,000%. Tesla's meteoric rise from a niche automaker to a global leader in electric vehicles and clean energy illustrates the immense financial rewards of investing early in innovative companies. This 13,000% return underscores the transformative potential of long-term investment strategies, where patience and belief in disruptive technology can result in extraordinary financial gains, as illustrated in @fig-tesla-stock. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Enhanced plot for Tesla Stock Investment with labels for selected years ggplot(tesla_data, aes(x = Date, y = Investment_Value)) + geom_line(color = "#0073C2FF", linewidth = 1.5) + # Use a refined blue color and thicker line geom_point(size = 5, color = "#FF5733", shape = 21, fill = "#FF5733") + # Use a refined orange color for points geom_text(aes(label = scales::comma(Investment_Value)), vjust = -1.2, hjust = 0.5, size = 3.5, color = "black", fontface = "bold") + # Slightly adjusted text size scale_x_date(date_labels = "%Y", breaks = "5 year", limits = c(as.Date("2008-01-01"), as.Date("2026-12-31"))) + scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, 20000000)) + # Set y-axis limit to 20 million labs(title = "Tesla Stock Investment Value on June 30th (2010-2024)", y = "Investment Value (in USD)", x = "Year") + theme_bw(base_size = 12) + # Use a minimal theme with base font size 12 theme( plot.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5, color = "#2C3E50"), # Adjusted title size axis.title = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold", color = "#2C3E50"), # Darker axis titles axis.text = element_text(size = 10, color = "#2C3E50"), # Darker axis text panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray85", linetype = "dashed"), # Softer gridlines panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), # Remove minor gridlines plot.margin = margin(20, 20, 20, 20) # Add a bit more margin for breathing space ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![This graph shows the exponential growth of a $109,000 investment in Tesla stock, reaching $14.39 million by 2024, highlighting significant returns over 14 years.](index_files/figure-html/fig-tesla-stock-1.png){#fig-tesla-stock width=672} ::: ::: ***Tesla Roadster Investment*** In contrast, the Tesla Roadster, purchased for $109,000 in 2010, followed a typical luxury car depreciation curve. It lost 20% of its value in the first year, 10% annually for the next four years, and then depreciated at a slower rate of 5% per year. By 2024, the Roadster's value had dropped to under $40,000, representing a decline of over 63% from its original price, as illustrated in @tbl-roadster. While the Roadster was a symbol of technological innovation, its financial performance exemplifies the inevitable depreciation of luxury vehicles. This stark contrast highlights the significant disparity in wealth accumulation between an appreciating asset like Tesla stock and a depreciating asset like the car. ::: {#tbl-roadster .cell tbl-cap='This graph illustrates the depreciation of the Tesla Roadster from its initial value of $109,000 in 2010 to $44,269 by 2024, showing a steady decline in value over time.'} ```{.r .cell-code} kableExtra::kable(highlighted_points, format = "html", caption = "Tesla Roadster Value Depreciation Over Time") %>% kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"), full_width = F, position = "left") %>% column_spec(2, bold = T, color = "white", background = "steelblue") %>% row_spec(0, bold = T) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Tesla Roadster Value Depreciation Over Time
Date Value
2010-06-30 109000.00
2015-06-30 57211.92
2020-06-30 44269.49
2024-07-01 44269.49
````` ::: ::: ### Conclusion This analysis highlights the stark financial contrast between investing in Tesla stock and purchasing a Tesla Roadster, directly addressing the initial question. While the Roadster, as a luxury asset, provided short-term prestige, it depreciated by over 60% from its original value within 14 years. In contrast, Tesla stock saw a remarkable growth of over 13,000%, turning a $109,000 investment in 2010 into $14.39 million by 2024. These findings underscore the long-term financial advantages of investing in disruptive, future-focused companies. Tesla stock exemplifies how innovation and technological advancements can yield extraordinary financial returns. Meanwhile, the Roadster’s depreciation follows the predictable pattern seen with luxury goods. Ultimately, this comparison emphasizes that patience, foresight, and a focus on emerging technologies can significantly enhance wealth-building potential over time. ### References - **Gründl, H., M. Dong and J. Gal (2016), "The evolution of insurer portfolio investment strategies for long-term investing", OECD Journal**: Financial Market Trends, vol. 2016/2, . - **Storchmann, K. (2004). On the Depreciation of Automobiles**: An International Comparison. Transportation, 31(4), pp.371–408. .
